review.title: Expert Opinion Extraction from a Biomedical Database
review.abstract: In this paper, we tackle the problem of extracting frequent opinions from uncertain databases. We introduce the foundation of an opinion mining approach with the definition of pattern and support measure. The support measure is derived from the commitment definition. A new algorithm called OpMiner that extracts the set of frequent opinions modelled as a mass functions is detailed. Finally, we apply our approach on a real-world biomedical database that stores opinions of experts to evaluate the reliability level of biomedical data. Performance analysis showed a better quality patterns for our proposed model in comparison with literature-based methods.

metadata.title: Expert Opinion Extraction from a Biomedical Database

sections.text: ar Xiv: 170 9.03 270v 1 [cs.A I] 1 1se pKeywords: Uncertain Database, Data Mining, Opinion, OpMiner.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: Data insecurity has challenged almost all types of data mining tasks, creating a need for insecure data mining patterns. Uncertainty is inherent in data from many different fields, including social networks and computer science. [1] The problem of pattern mining, or finding common patterns in data, has been extensively investigated in deterministic databases since its introduction by Aggrawal et al. [3] and in the area of insecure databases [4]. Insecure databases have brought more flexibility in data representation [5]. For example, the mass functions of evidence theory are comparable to expert opinion because they provide detailed answers to a number of answer elements. They also allow to model the degree of belief in a question. Therefore, databases that distort mass functions (commonly referred to as evidence databases) are considered a database for expert opinions and imperfect data. What classical approaches have in common is that they extract answers (as long as they are redacted).

sections.heading: 2 Preliminaries
sections.text: The Evidence Theory or Dempster-Shafer Theory [11,12] proposes a robust formalism for modeling uncertainty. Evidence Theory is based on several bases, such as the Basic Belief Assignment (BBA). A BBA m is the mapping of elements of Power Set 2B to [0, 1]: m: 2B − → [0, 1] 4 A pattern is often cited when its calculated support (i.e. frequency in the database) is higher or equal to a fixed threshold set by an expert, setting the framework of the distinction. It is the series of possible answers to an addressed problem and is composed of N exhaustive and exclusive hypotheses: B = {H1, H2, HN}.A BBA m is limited by: {A ² qm (A) = 1m (we). Each subset X of 2B > 0 is referred to as a focal element.

sections.heading: 3 Extraction opinion patterns over evidential databases
sections.text: In the following section we examine the plausibility-based relationship between two BBAs in evidence theory.

sections.heading: 3.2 Mining opinions over evidential databases
sections.text: In an evidential database not included in the series examined, we analyze whether there is a BBA based on a BBA. An itemset (so-called pattern) corresponds to a constellation of several BBAs having different domains. (1) An itemset (so-called pattern) corresponds to a constellation of several BBAs having different evidence. (2) We look at an evidential database and the itemset X, where the frequency of occurrence of an article x = mi in a transaction Ti can be calculated as follows: M (0, 1) x 7 → C (x, mij), where mij (5) M (S) j (S) i is the set of BBAs in the Ti series of attributes j j j. As shown above, the SupTi is a measurement that calculates whether x is in the Ti series.

sections.heading: 4 Experiments: Data reliability assessment using biomedical expert opinion
sections.text: The study of the effects of muscle morphology and mechanics on movement, and the risk of injury, was carried out at the core of many studies, sometimes with contradictory results. Frequently, different measurement methods were used, making it impossible to compare the results and draw patterns [15]. In this section, we will examine the opinion of several experts on collected measurement data. To do this, we were asked to collect the data through a systematic pro-cess review of 20 data sources (essays) from reliable search engines (PubMed and ScienceDirect). Data is collected on 7 parameters relating to muscle morphology, mechanics and motion analysis. Four main questions were asked to experts on measurement techniques (Q1), experimental protocols (Q2), number of samples (Q3) and range of values (Q4). An expert opinion database of 20 contacted experts with different expertise (medical imaging, motion analysis). Five grades were possible.
